title: Prosodic Dissonance
abstract: In popular and scholarly discourse on texted music and music-speech intersections, the prevailing assumption is that the linguistic features of the lyrics (e.g., syllabic stress) align with the way the lyrics are sung (e.g., phenomenal accent in or affecting the melody)—or, if not, that they should. However, not onlycantext and music conflict, but they do so in a variety of ways, to varying degrees, and with different effects on our listening experience. I defineprosodic dissonanceas any conflict between the prosodic linguistic features and musical rendition of text. This could include misalignment between syllabic and durational/registral stress, between spoken and sung phrases, or between spoken and sung intonation. Prosodic dissonance/consonance can also interact with rhyme, vowel shape, parallelism, and syncopation. To recognize prosodic dissonance, I (1) determine the prosody for the lyrics as spoken, (2) determine the prosody for the melody as sung, (3) identify mismatches as dissonances, (4) consider the effect of the surrounding melody/lyrics, (5) consider alternate pronunciations or hearings that might account for it, and (6) consider the perceptual and analytical implications. This article focuses on prosodic dissonance in popular music, with longer analyses of Kesha’s “Tonight” (2020), Royal & the Serpent’s “Overwhelmed” (2020), and Rina Sawayama’s “This Hell” (2022).

FN0.text: * To reference this paper, please use she/her or they/them pronouns and cite the author by first name (e.g. Eron 2024).

FN1.text: 1. Thank you to my colleague and friend Suraj Saifullah for providing me with this example.

FN2.text: 2. For several anecdotal examples, see the Disboards forum by Claudia1 , the r/popheads Reddit thread by Santa_Bond69 , the song’s listing in TVTropes , reference to “syllabic phrasing” in Entertainment Weekly ’s ranking of all of Katy Perry’s songs, Coutts ( 2021 blog post), Gamboa ( 2013 Newsday review), McClellan ( 2013 blog post), Newman ( 2013 Uproxx review), and Pattison ( 2014 ). A search for “syllable emphasis unconditionally katy perry” on Twitter also yields many representative judgments.

FN3.text: 3. For a helpful review of many of the concepts below, see Music, Language, and the Brain ( Patel 2010 ) and the Lexical Stress chapter in The Handbook of Speech Perception ( Cutler 2008 ).

FN4.text: 4. Some scholarship, such as Heffner and Slevc ( 2015 ), Schreuder ( 2006 ), and Temperley ( 2022 ), has explicitly highlighted these commonalities between music and language.

FN5.text: 5. These features of English stress, as well as the stress- vs. syllable-timed language dichotomy, are widespread in mid-20th-century linguistics; once again, see Patel ( 2010 ). Representative primary sources include Pike ( 1945 ), generally considered to be the original source of the stress/syllable dichotomy; Burzio’s influential Principles of English Stress ( 1994 ); Chomsky & Halle ( 1968 ), who not only offer guidelines on word pronunciation but also methods for quantifying stress; and Fry ( 1955 ), who found that duration is a better indicator of stress than intensity on spectrograms.

FN6.text: 6. Some other languages have features that English does not, such as tones, which are more influential to texted music in those languages. This is well documented; for representative examples, see Kirby and Ladd ( 2016 ), McPherson and Ryan ( 2018 ), and Proto ( 2015 ).

FN7.text: 7. List ( 1963 ) provides examples of many of these cultural distinctions.

FN8.text: 8. For a sampling of recent research on this topic, see Adams ( 2008 ; 2009 ), Duinker ( 2022 ), Ohriner ( 2019a , 2019b ), Patel ( 2010 ), Salley ( 2011 ), Temperley ( 1999 ), and VanderStel ( 2021 ).

FN9.text: 9. As a demonstration of this assumption, see Lee, Brown, and Müllensiefen ( 2017 ); Palmer and Kelly ( 1992 ); Patel ( 2010 ); Proto ( 2015 ); Rodríguez-Vásquez ( 2010 ); Tait, Tabain, and Sykes ( 2014 ); and Temperley and Temperley ( 2011 ; 2013 ). The latter remarks, in particular, that the “lack of interaction between the two sources of rhythmic structure” is interesting (539).

Küster ( 2022 ) returns to rhetoric-centered music theories of the 18 th century to suggest that prosody should factor into performance of phrase, while 21 st -century songwriting instruction in textbooks and blog posts alike warn against the type of mismatches in Example 1 above (e.g. Perricone 2018 and Pattison 2014 ).

FN14.text: 14. I use “dissonance” here in the same sense of misalignment as Krebs ( 1999 ); prosodic consonance would be the alignment of these features. This article focuses primarily on stress, which is the main connotation of “prosody” for English; which elements are phonemic or suprasegmental depends on the language (see fn. 39 below) and would redefine prosodic dissonance accordingly.

FN15.text: 15. Of course, other languages also have lexical categories and semantic content, and other spoken languages also have vowels.

However, we can still say with confidence that Olivia Rodrigo’s isochronous melody clashes more actively with an idiomatic, “maximally even” distribution of spoken syllables compared to Dua Lipa’s.

Interestingly, this type of prosodic dissonance is more widely accepted as an expressive choice rather than a mistake by fans of the genre, to the point that rap and hip-hop are discussed on the Wikipedia page for “internal rhymes” and fans post on forums asking for suggestions of rappers that use internal and slant rhymes. For a representative analysis of internal rhyme, see Griffiths ( 2012 ). Of course, my intention is not to add a negative value judgment to expressive rhyme creation and emphasis, but to highlight that prosodic dissonance has already entered mainstream aesthetic values in some contexts.

I would expect that listeners would default to a syncopated hearing in an ambiguous case, and that experiencing syncopation rather than prosodic dissonance would be more easily available in common metric positions for syncopation (e.g., second- and fourth-position syncopation, see Temperley 2019 ; 2021 ).

Phrase perception is also repeatedly a subject of music cognition studies.
